Fig. 7 Synergistic effects of adsorption and photocatalysis in MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst for remediation of phenanthrene-contaminated saline-alkaline soils Meng Xia Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Shuai Zhang Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation Kaihao Xu Visualization Formal analysis Chengxue Zhang Validation Data curation Xiaocong Wang Validation Data curation Key Laboratory of Oasis Ecology of Ministry of Education, College of Ecology and Environment, Xinjiang University, Urumqi 830046, China Key Laboratory of Oasis Ecology of Ministry of Education, College of Ecology and Environment, Xinjiang University Urumqi 830046 China Key Laboratory of Oasis Ecology of Ministry of Education, College of Ecology and Environment, Xinjiang University, Urumqi 830046, China ⁎ Corresponding author. In arid and semi-arid areas, the remediation of saline-alkaline soils polluted by organic contaminants is challenging. In this study, the adsorption–photocatalysis synergistic removal of organic contaminants was realised using the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, and the saline-alkaline soils were remediated simultaneously. The adsorption isotherm of catalyst conformed to Langmuir model, and the photocatalytic degradation of PHE in an optimal visible light system achieved a PHE degradation efficiency of up to 86.2 % within 30 min. Based on the identification of active oxygen species, the PHE photocatalytic degradation was primarily driven by holes (h+) and superoxide radicals (·O2 -), followed by hydroxyl radicals (·OH) and singlet oxygen (1O2). Furthermore, the determined physical and chemical properties of the saline-alkaline soils indicated that the soil pH value decreased to 6.82, effectively increasing the absorbable nitrogen content and improving soil fertility. This study offers a new strategy for the removal of organic contaminants under special soil medium conditions. Graphical Abstract Keywords Photocatalysis MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst Saline-alkaline soils pollution remediation Absorption Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are a typical class of persistent organic pollutants, consisting of two or more benzene rings, produced primarily from fossil industrial processes. They have long been the focus of attention owing to their "triple-induced" effects and serious health risks [1,2]. PAHs are easily adsorbed onto soil particles because of their hydrophobicity, bioaccumulation, and low solubility, and studies have shown that more than 90 % of PAHs in the environment are loaded into the soil [3]. The long-term retention of pollutants in the soil reduces the permeability and water infiltration capacity, thus deepening soil solidification and changing the properties of the soil. In particular, in arid and semi-arid regions, most PAH-contaminated soils are saline-alkaline soils, which are characterised by high alkalinity and salinity, low water-holding capacity, low organic matter content, and poor aeration, aggravating the difficulty of the PAHs treatment process. Saline-alkaline soils also require remediation. Therefore, the effective treatment of PAH-contaminated saline-alkaline soils, simultaneously realising the degradation of PAHs contaminants and the remediation of the saline-alkaline soils, is urgently required to restore the ecological function of soil. Various remediation technologies, including physical, chemical, and biological processes [4], have been developed to remove PAHs from soil. Among these processes, chemical remediation is considered to be a rapid and effective technology for degrading PAHs in soils. For example, chemical oxidation technologies using H2O2, Fenton reagent, persulfate, and permanganate as oxidants can efficiently degrade organic contaminants in soil [5]. Unfortunately, the use of chemical oxidants deteriorates soil quality and damages soil ecosystems. Recently, photocatalytic degradation technology using solar energy as the driving force has attracted extensive attention for soil remediation using chemical processes. Photocatalytic technology is a green, clean, low cost, and highly stable method that can convert light energy into chemical energy through catalytic materials. It possesses great potential for degrading and treating organic contaminants [6]. Yin et al. [7] synthesised TiO2/α-FeOOH composite photocatalysts, applied them for the degradation of 40 mg·kg−1 fluoranthene in soil with an initial pH of 6.8, and achieved a degradation efficiency of 28 %. Wang et al. [8] utilised the excellent visible light-driven photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4/Fe3O4 for the degradation of phenanthrene (PHE) in a neutral soil environment (pH=6.31), obtaining a degradation efficiency of 92.26 % over 120 min. Notably, studies on the photocatalytic degradation of PAHs in saline-alkaline soils are still rare, and detailed investigations, such as the effects of soil physicochemical properties, are scarcely elucidated. Additionally, the degradation efficiency of PAHs in the existing photocatalytic systems is rather limited, which incapacitates the further development of soil ecological function. Previous studies on the photocatalytic degradation of PAHs in soil (Table S1) have not addressed several bottlenecks. For example, the mass transfer of PAHs in soil is limited, which hinders their interaction with the catalyst active sites and leads to a lower rate of photocatalytic degradation. In addition, the penetration of light into soil is very limited [9], and commonly used photocatalysts such as TiO2 can only be activated by UV light or a small amount of visible light and have low conversion efficiency from light energy to chemical energy [8]. Thus, the high adsorption and photocatalytic performance of the catalysts are of great significance for improving the degradation performance of pollutants and efficiently utilising solar energy. Porous crystalline metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) synthesised by the coordination of metal ions/clusters and organic ligands possess high specific surface area, high porosity, a well-defined porous structure, and structural tunability [10–12], and have frequently been used as functional materials in several applications, such as adsorption [13], biomedicine [14], sensors [15], and catalysis [16–18]. In particular, iron-based MOFs (Fe-MOFs) confer semiconducting properties to the material owing to the presence of the Fe-O group and exhibit photocatalytic activity when exposed to visible light[19]. Viswanathan et al. [20] found that 91 % of p-nitrophenol, 99 % of Rhodamine B (RhB), and 94 % of methylene blue were degraded in an aqueous solution in 70–80 min by using Ag/AgCl@MIL-88A(Fe) as a catalyst under sunlight. Lui et al. [21] fabricated graphene oxide hybridized MIL-88A(Fe) microrods using a facile one-pot solvothermal method and found that RhB was almost completely degraded within 80 min in a visible-light aqueous system. Notably, the large swelling effect of Fe-MOFs in polar solvents is of great significance for mass transfer during photocatalytic processes [22]. Moreover, Fe-MOFs can be saturated with reactive solvents via Lewis acid–base interactions, thus potentially conferring acidity sites [23], which play an important role in the improvement of soil alkalinity. Therefore, Fe-MOF catalysts can not only efficiently degrade organic contaminants by relying on their excellent adsorption and photocatalytic properties but also improve saline-alkaline soils by relying on their physicochemical properties. In this study, PHE was chosen as the representative of PAHs because it was highly resistant to sunlight and challenging to degrade owing to its stable three-ring structure. MIL-88A(Fe) was prepared as the catalyst for the degradation of PHE. The adsorption–photocatalytic performance of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst for PHE removal was systematically investigated, and the effect of the catalytic system under a saline-alkaline soils background was explored. In addition, the degradation mechanism of PHE under the action of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was revealed, and the saline-alkaline soils improvement effect was verified. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Iron chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6 H2O, 99 %), fumaric acid (C4H4O4, 99.5 %), phenanthrene (PHE, 97 %), dichloromethane (DCM, 99.5 %), ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.9 %), p-benzoquinone (p-BQ, 99.5 %), potassium iodide (KI, 99 %), isopropyl alcohol (IPA, 99.7 %), potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7, 99.8 %), L-Histidine (L-His, 99 %) and acetonitrile (C2H3N, HPLC–grade solvent, 99.9 %) were purchased from Aladdin. All reagents were used as-received without further purification. Saline-alkaline soil samples were collected from the topsoil (0–20 cm) of Xinjiang University Boda Campus. The soil samples were shade-dried and passed through 20-mesh and 60-mesh sieves to remove large gravel and impurities. The samples were also sterilised at 105 °C for 24 h to exclude microbial disturbances. The soil samples were then mixed thoroughly to ensure homogeneity and stored in dark, airtight containers at room temperature for further use. The PHE-contaminated saline-alkaline soils used in the experiment were artificially prepared by uniformly blending a certain amount of PHE with the saline-alkaline soils. Typically, a DCM solution of PHE was added to the pretreated saline-alkaline soils; after stirring, the samples were placed away from light. After complete evaporation of the DCM solution, the soil samples were sealed in a refrigerator at 4 °C for 1 month for further use. The theoretical concentration of the PHE-contaminated saline-alkaline soil was approximately 200 mg·kg−1. The physicochemical properties of the PHE-contaminated saline-alkaline soils were determined, as shown in Table S2. 2.2 Catalyst preparation MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was synthesized by a hydrothermal method according to a previous report [24]. Typically, 20 mmol of iron chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6 H2O), 20 mmol of fumaric acid (C4H4O4), and 150 mL of deionized water were mixed homogeneously in the vessel, and heated in a 200 mL Teflon reactor to 70 ℃ for 12 h to initiate crystallization reaction. After that, the cooled reaction mixtures were centrifuged and washed with ethanol and water for several times to obtain a solid powder, followed by dried at 80 °C for 24 h. The final solid powder was gained as MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal structures of the prepared materials were analysed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 Advance, Bruker, Germany) using Cu-Kα as the radiation source over a 2θ range of 5°-80°. The chemical bonds and functional groups of the samples were tested by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, Bruker, Germany) in the wavelength range of 400–4000 nm with KBr as the reference sample. The surface morphology and microstructure were observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, HITACHI SU8010). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi) was performed to characterise the surface elemental compositions. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained with a surface analyser (ASAP2460) using the BET method, and the pore size distribution and specific surface area of the catalyst were analysed. The iron content in the catalyst was determined using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Perkin Elmer Optima 2100 DV). UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS, UV-3600) was also performed, using BaSO4 as the standard reference in the wavelength range of 200–800 nm. Transient photocurrent (TPC) and Mott–Schottky (M–S) curves were obtained separately using a che660 electrochemical workstation. The tests were performed using a three-electrode system with a glassy carbon electrode as the working electrode, a platinum electrode as the counter electrode, and an Ag/AgCl standard calomel electrode as the reference electrode. 2.4 Reaction tests and product analysis The photocatalytic degradation reactions of PHE were carried out in a chamber equipped with a 300 W xenon lamp with a 420 nm cut off filter. The distance between the xenon lamp and the samples was 15 cm, and the reaction temperature was controlled at 20 ℃ by a constant temperature water bath. For all photocatalytic degradation reactions, a mixture of 5.00 g of the PHE-contaminated saline-alkaline soils and a certain amount of catalyst was evenly distributed at the bottom of the reaction apparatus, and the dark adsorption was carried out for specific time periods to allow the reaction system to reach equilibrium, and the adsorption process was described in the Supplementary Materials. During the photocatalytic degradation process, the soil water content was maintained at approximately 60 %; a spray was used to compensate for the loss of water. The mixed samples were agitated at regular intervals to ensure a uniform and well-oxygenated reaction. After the reaction, the mixed samples were freeze-dried for subsequent extraction and investigation. The degradation intermediates were analysed using a GC–MS system (Agilent 5977 A GC with a 7890B Series mass spectrometer) equipped with an Agilent DB EUPAH column (122–5532, 30 m×250 µm×0.25 µm), as described in the Supplementary Materials. Each experiment was repeated to determine the data reproducibility. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterisation of catalysts structure The morphology of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was observed using SEM. As shown in Fig. 1(a) and (b), MIL-88A(Fe) had a regular needle shape with particle sizes of approximately 0.4–1.1 µm, and presented a smooth surface [24]. Furthermore, the crystallographic phase structures of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst were examined using XRD, as shown in Fig. 1(c). The characteristic peaks of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst appeared at 2θ=8.1°, 12.1°, and 20.1°, corresponding to the (100), (101), and (002) crystal planes of the catalyst, respectively [25,26]. The well-demarcated diffraction peaks demonstrated that the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst with a highly crystalline Fe(III) phase was successfully synthesised [24]. To illustrate the functional groups and chemical structure of MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, the FT-IR spectra was obtained in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. As shown in Fig. 1(d), the peak at 566 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibration of the Fe–O bonds, demonstrating that the carboxyl group of the organic linker was attached to the inorganic metal in the Fe–oxo cluster [27,28]. The peak at 672 cm−1 was attributed to the out-of-plane C–H bending of olefins [29]. The stretching vibration of C–H and the bending vibration of C–C in trans-diene were detected at 980 and 1218 cm−1, respectively [24]. The peaks at 1397 and 1608 cm−1 were the result of the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxyl group (-COOH) bonds in the C4H4O4 [21,30], while the peak at 1708 cm−1 was attributed to the CO stretching bond of carboxylate[29]. The broad peak found between 2695 and 3680 cm−1 was caused by the -OH stretching vibrations of the adsorbed water molecules [31]. The FT-IR spectrum of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst matched well with those previously reported [24]. XPS was conducted to further investigate the surface elemental compositions and chemical states of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst. As observed from the spectrum in Fig. 2(a), Fe, O, and C were present in the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst. The high-resolution C1s spectrum could be divided into two peaks with binding energies of 288.7 and 284.8 eV (Fig. 2(b)), corresponding to the carbonyl group (CO) and C–C bonds of C4H4O4, respectively [32]. The high-resolution O1s spectrum revealed that the three peaks at binding energies of 532.2, 533.6, and 530.4 eV corresponded to the OH, C–O/CO, and Fe-O bonds [26,33], respectively. The XPS spectra of Fe 2p demonstrated Fe 2p1/2, Fe 2p3/2, and satellite signal peaks at 725.6, 712.2, 717.7 eV, respectively [34,35]. These fitted peaks were attributed to Fe(III), indicating the existence of Fe(III) in the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst structure. Adsorption capacity being a crucial factor in the efficient removal of contaminants from soil, the porous properties of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst were investigated using the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. S1). The MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst exhibited type IV adsorption properties with H3 hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of a mesoporous structure in the sample. The pore sizes ranged from 2 to 90 nm, further confirming this conclusion, which was in agreement with the reports of Thi-Phuong-Thao Vu et al. [36] and Jiabao Gu et al. [29]. The mesoporous structure not only enhanced the interaction between pollutants and the active sites but also improved the adsorption–photocatalytic process [37]. The MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst had a high BET surface areas (SBET) of 45.87 m2·g−1, mesoporous specific surface area (Smeso) of 34.21 m2·g−1, total pore volumes (Vtotal) of 0.086 cm³·g−1, and mesopores volumes (Vmecro) of 0.069 cm³·g−1, as shown in Table S3. Therefore, the large specific surface area and pore size of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst could provide free mass diffusion and abundant reactive active sites during the reaction process, which shortened the distance of photogenerated carrier migration and increased the contact frequency between the contaminants and catalysts, thus increasing the contaminant degradation efficiency [38]. In conclusion, the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was successfully prepared, as indicated by the combined results of the XPS, XRD, FT-IR, SEM, and N2 adsorption–desorption analyses. 3.2 Optical properties of catalysts The optical absorption properties and energy band gap of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst were assessed using UV–vis DRS. As shown in Fig. 3(a), ligand–metal charge transfer due to the presence of the Fe-O groups allowed the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst to absorb visible light in the range of 200–600 nm [36]. Additionally, the absorption in the wavelength range of 300–500 nm, with an absorption edge at 440 nm, was caused by the d-d transition of Fe(III) [25,39]. These results demonstrated the susceptibility of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst to excitation by visible light. Using the Tauc formula [40] (Eq. (S6)), the energy band gaps of the samples were calculated to assess the redox capacity of the photocatalyst. The band gap (Eg) of the as-prepared MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was estimated to be 3.04 eV (Fig. 3(a)). To further investigate the energy band structure of the samples, the M–S spectra were used to analyse the conductivity and determine the flat band potential (Efb) of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3(b), at a frequency of 1500 Hz, the slope of the curve for the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was positive, indicating that it was an n-type semiconductors, which was consistent with previous results [41]. Based on the x-axis intercept of the linear portion of the M–S plot, the Efb (vs. Ag/AgCl) of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was determined to be −0.85 eV (Fig. 3(b)). According to the Nernst formula [42], the Efb (vs. NHE) of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was equivalent to −0.65 eV [42]. Because the Efb (NHE) of an n-type semiconductor is typically 0.1 eV more positive than its conduction band potential (ECB) [43], the ECB of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was approximately −0.75 eV (vs. NHE). Based on the empirical formula, EVB = ECB + Eg, the valence band potentials (EVB) of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was calculated to be 2.29 eV, as shown in Fig. 3(d). A higher photocurrent intensity is known to imply more efficient separation of electron–hole pairs (e- CB–hVB +) [44,45]. Thus, the efficiency of carrier separation and migration was studied using TPC measurements, as shown in Fig. 3(c). The MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst showed good photocurrent reproducibility over several light–dark cycles, indicating that the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was photoresponsive and could more effectively separate and transfer photoelectrons upon visible light irradiation. The higher e- CB–hVB + separation efficiency could trigger the generation of a series of active radicals and promote photocatalysis. 3.3 Synergistic effect of adsorption and photocatalysis in MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst The degradation of PHE was conducted under dark and visible light conditions to investigate the catalytic performance of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, and the ratio of catalyst with the best performance was determined, as shown in Fig. 4(a). The MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst exhibited superior adsorption capabilities for PHE; the adsorption removal efficiency remained steady after approximately 60 min, reaching 35 %-60 %, which was significantly different from the results reported in previous studies [46,47]. Such a distinctive difference in the contaminant adsorption removal efficiency indicated that the adsorption capacity of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was a important factor in the efficient removal of organic contaminants from the saline-alkaline soil. Consequently, the adsorption kinetic curves of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst were investigated to gain insight into the corresponding adsorption behaviour. As exhibited in Fig. 4(b), the adsorption of PHE mainly occurred in the first 10 min; the adsorption process reached equilibrium within 40 min, corresponding to an adsorption capacity of 64.8–114.5 mg·kg−1. Furthermore, the pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order models were applied to fit the experimental adsorption data using Eq. (S2) and Eq. (S3). As indicated in Table S4, both kinetic models fitted the data well with high correlation coefficients, suggesting that the adsorption ability of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst towards PHE was affected by multiple factors; specifically, the adsorption process was dominated by physical and chemical adsorption[40], and the rate of physical adsorption was faster than that of chemical adsorption (Table S4). To further understand the interaction between the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst and PHE, the isotherms were analysed using the Langmuir and Freundlich models, as expressed in Eq. (S4) and Eq. (S5). Fig. 4(d) depicts the PHE adsorption capacity of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst as a function of the PHE concentration. Comparing the Langmuir isotherm model (R1 2 = 0.994) and the Freundlich isotherm model (R2 2 = 0.933), the Langmuir model showed a higher R2 value (R1 2 = 0.994), confirming the monolayer coverage of PHE on the surface of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst (Table S5). Consequently, the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst could quickly adsorb PHE contaminants on its surface via physical and chemical adsorption. Based on previous research, the adsorption process was primarily attributed to π-π interactions and hydrophobic effects[48]. The strong adsorption ability of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst could shorten the migration distance of the free radicals to a certain extent, accelerating the photodegradation of PHE on the catalyst surface. The adsorption process increased the contaminant concentration around the catalytic active sites on the surface of the catalyst, thus accelerating contaminants removal. However, this process did not involve the degradation of organic contaminants [31]; thus, an advanced oxidation process had to be combined with adsorption to remove PHE. As depicted in Fig. 4(a), the degradation efficiency of PHE was 8.40 % without the catalyst after 30 min of light exposure, and the degradation efficiency dramatically improved to 62.88 %, 86.23 %, and 82.40 %, respectively, after the introduction of different doses of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst (1, 3, and 5 wt%). The results indicated that the photocatalytic activity of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst dominated the photodegradation of PHE, mainly because the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst generated certain active substances to degrade PHE under the visible light irradiation. Furthermore, upon increasing the doses of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, the photodegradation efficiency of PHE initially increased and then reached the plateau, indicating that the appropriate dosage of catalyst was beneficial to the photocatalytic degradation process. Insufficient catalysts doses leaded to insufficient active substances, resulting in reduced degradation efficiency, while excessive catalysts doses could cause agglomeration of the catalyst particles, reduce the number of available active sites, and ultimately affect the photodegradation efficiency. Coincidently, this phenomenon was consistent with the results of previous studies [49,50]. In addition, the photodegradation reaction followed the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, which was consistent with the results of previous studies [51,52], as shown in Fig. 4(c). The rate constants (k) of the first-order kinetics under different dosages (1, 3, and 5 wt%) of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was 0.017, 0.048, and 0.027 min−1, respectively, indicating that the catalyst significantly accelerated the photodegradation of PHE. In particular, the 3 wt% MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst with sufficient active sites displayed the optimal PHE photodegradation efficiency and rate. Thus, the degradation efficiency of PHE in the saline-alkaline soil was significantly improved by the remarkable adsorption–photocatalytic synergistic effects of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst. The recyclability of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst in liquid system was investigated with reference to previous studies [53]. After every run, the mixture was centrifuged to collect the solid substances and then washed with an anhydrous ethanol solution to remove the organic matter for the next reaction. As shown in Fig. S2, the degradation efficiency of PHE exhibited virtually no change after repeated use of the catalyst, and the degradation efficiency of PHE remained >80 %. After each run, the catalysts were characterised by ICP-OES (Fig. S2) and XRD (Fig. S3). The results indicated that there was almost no iron metal leaching from the catalyst. Moreover, the crystal structure of the catalyst remained integrity before and after the reaction. Therefore, these results confirmed the excellent catalytic stability of MIL-88A (Fe) catalyst. 3.4 Factors affecting adsorption–photocatalytic activity in saline-alkaline soil background Reaction conditions are important factors that can dramatically influence adsorption–photocatalytic processes. Particularly, in a saline-alkaline soil background, the water content in the soil directly affects the mass transfer of PHE because of the tight binding of the PAHs molecules to the soil matrix[54,55], limiting the adsorption–photocatalytic degradation of PHE. The effect of different water contents, ranging from 10 % to 100 %, on the removal of PHE was studied, as shown in Fig. 5(a). The different water contents had a substantial impact on the adsorption–photocatalytic process of PHE with the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, and the removal efficiency of PHE tended to increase and then decrease with increasing water content. The adsorption–photocatalytic degradation efficiency of PHE reached a maximum value of 86.23 % at a water content of 60 %, and the residual amount of PHE in the soil was 25.99 mg·kg−1. This result was ascribed to the following possible reasons: an appropriately increase in water content not only promoted the transmittance of visible light in the saline-alkaline soil but also enhanced the mass transfer capacity of the contaminants, thereby increasing the degradation efficiency of PHE[9]. However, as the water content continues to increased, the volume of the reaction system increased and the probability of contact between the photocatalyst and PHE decreased[7]. Considering the background of saline-alkaline soils in arid and semi-arid areas, that is, low water content and small permeability coefficient, controlling the water content at approximately 40 % was appropriate. In the adsorption–photocatalytic processes of organic contaminants, pH plays a crucial role because it is not only closely related to the chemical and mineralogical properties of the soil (such as zeta potential, cation-exchange capacity, and redox potential) but also affects adsorption directly by changing the surface charge of the catalyst [7,56]. Soils with different initial pH values, including acidic (pH=2.50), neutral (pH=7.24), and alkaline (pH=8.67) soils, were selected to explore the effect of pH on the degradation of PHE, and the results are shown in Fig. 5(b). The results indicated that the adsorption and photocatalytic effects of PHE were optimal in alkaline soil, with a total degradation efficiency of 84.36 %, whereas the photocatalytic effect of PHE dramatically decreased in acidic and neutral soils, resulting in a decrease in the total degradation efficiency of PHE. This phenomenon was attributed to the surface of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst being positively charged under acidic conditions and PHE also being positively charged after protonation, which generated electrostatic repulsion between them, reducing the photocatalytic effect of PHE and ultimately leading to a decrease in the degradation efficiency. By contrast, under alkaline conditions, the positively charged protonated PHE was easily adsorbed onto the negatively charged surface of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, thereby improving the degradation ability of PHE in the saline-alkaline soils[57]. Previous studies reached similar conclusions, suggesting that the surface charge of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was negative at pH > 7 and positive at pH < 7[36]. This result indicated that the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst played a dominant role in effective PHE degradation in the saline-alkaline soils. Different initial PHE concentrations (60, 200, 300, and 600 mg·kg−1) were investigated to explore the effect of contaminant concentration. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the removal performance of PHE gradually decreased with the increase of initial concentration; however, the removal efficiency of PHE could still be maintained at 35 % when the initial PHE concentration was 600 mg·kg−1, indicating that the high photocatalytic activity of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst could maintain the degradation effect even at a high concentration of PHE in the saline-alkaline soils. Furthermore, real soil, especially saline-alkaline soils, typically contain a large number of co-existing ions, such as Na+, K+, NO3 −, and SO4 2− [58], which might affect the adsorption–photocatalytic system. The effect of co-existing ions on the PHE removal efficiency with the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was tested, as shown in Table S6. Interestingly, the content of the co-existing ions Na+, K+, and SO4 2− before and after the reaction remained largely the same; however, the content of NO3 − ion was significantly reduced, with a certain amount of NH4 + ion generated, indicating that the NO3 − ion was involved in the photocatalytic process and was reduced to NH4 + ion under the action of e-. This phenomenon indicated that the PHE degradation efficiencies were hardly affected by the co-existing ions Na+, K+, and SO4 2−, but the presence of NO3 − ion greatly affected the photocatalytic process. This was verified by the fact that the PHE degradation performance declined in fertile soil with higher NO3 − ions; the reduction of NO3 − by e- resulted in a decrease in the production of ROSs, which in turn lead to a decrease in the degradation efficiency of PHE (Table S6). Notably, in the background of the saline-alkaline soils, the reduction of NO3 − ion to NH4 + ion was extremely advantageous, greatly improving the fertility of the saline-alkaline soils and benefitting the soil ecological environment. 3.5 Exploration of synergistic reaction mechanism Based on the results of the previous discussion, because the photocatalysis was a rate-determining step in the reaction system, quenching tests were carried out to determine the presence of ROSs to understand the photocatalytic action of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst. As mentioned in previous studies [59,60], the para-benzoquinone (p-BQ), isopropyl alcohol (IPA), K2Cr2O7, KI, and l-histidine (L-His) were selected as the free radical scavengers of ·O2 -, ·OH, e-, h+, and 1O2, respectively. As depicted in Fig. 6(a), upon the introduction of K2Cr2O7, p-BQ, or KI into the reaction system, the degradation efficiencies of PHE decreased to 22.72 %, 40.41 %, or 36.77 %, respectively, indicating that ·O2 − and h+ were the predominant active species in the reaction system. As IPA or L-His were added into the system, the degradation efficiencies of PHE decreased to 68.21 % or 46.90 %, respectively, suggesting that ·OH and 1O2 also participated in the degradation, playing a minor role. Electron spin resonance (ESR) was also applied to detect the generation of the ROSs in the reaction system. According to Fig. 6(b-d), in a well-illuminated environment, signals for DMPO-·OH (signal ratio 1:2:2:1), TEMP-1O2 (signal ratio 1:1:1), and DMPO-·O2 - (signal ratio 1:1:1:1) were observed[61]. These signals confirmed the production of the three active species ·OH, 1O2, and ·O2 - under visible light irradiation, which actively participated in the degradation process. Electrons tended to assemble in the conduction band of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, where they reacted with O2 to generate ·O2 -, resulting in the strong signal peak of ·O2 -. A large amount of h+ was primarily gathered in the valence band of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, which could directly oxidise and degrade the contaminants and indirectly oxidise ·O2 - and OH- to form 1O2 and ·OH. As a result, h+ expressed a stronger signal under dark conditions than under light conditions; meanwhile, the signal peak area for ·OH and 1O2 became relatively large under light conditions. To further confirm the principal ROSs in the PHE degradation reaction, the k values could be used to analyse the contribution ratios of the various ROSs to the degradation of PHE[31]. Considering the good correlation between the oxidation of PHE in the reaction system and the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, the contribution of ROSs could be determined. Eq. (1) was used to calculate the contribution ratios of ·OH, ·O2 −, and 1O2. As exhibited in Fig. 6(f), the contribution ratios of ·OH, ·O2 −, and 1O2 were recognised as 42.73 %, 74.06 %, and 68.37 %, respectively. Based on the quenching experiments, ESR results, and ROSs contribution calculation, the pivotal role of ·OH, ·O2 −, 1O2, and h+ synergy in the degradation of PHE was identified. (1) Relative contribution of ROSs = K obs − K obs scavenger K obs × 100 % Combined with the series of characterisation analyses, a photocatalytic degradation mechanism of PHE under the action of the MIL-88A(Fe) was proposed, as follows. In the catalytic process, PHE in the soil was excited to a higher energy state after absorbing light energy, which allowed energy transfer to ground state O2. O2 thus entered the excited state to form 1O2, leading to the oxidation and degradation of PHE (Eqs. (2)–(3)). Subsequently, the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst generated e- CB–hVB + stimulated by visible light (Eq. (4)). Given the calculated band gap locations of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, the conduction band potential of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was lower than the redox potential of O2/⋅O2 − (-0.33 eV), and the photoexcited electrons eventually accumulated in the conduction band of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, resulting in the O2 reaction to ⋅O2 − (Eq. (5))[62]. These as-generated ⋅O2 − species were further involved in the degradation process, and were converted to 1O2 ((Eqs. (6)–(7)). Furthermore, h+ was formed in the valence band of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, and played a critical role in the degradation process. The valence band potential of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was higher than the reduction potential of OH-/·OH (+1.99 eV). Thus, h+ could directly oxidise and degrade the contaminants; they also activated OH- to form ·OH, which could further participate in the degradation of the pollutants under visible light (Eq. (8)). Notably, the reaction system for the saline-alkaline soils could provide sufficient OH- to further promote the efficient degradation of the contaminants. Therefore, in the system of the visible photocatalytic degradation of PHE with the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, ·O2 -, ·OH, 1O2, and h+ all contributed to the degradation of PHE (Eq. (9)). (2) PHE + hv → PHE* (3) PHE* + O2 → PHE + 1O2 (4) MIL-88A + hv →MIL-88A* (e- + h+) (5) e- + O2 → ·O2 - (6) O2 - + h+ → 1O2 (7) h+ + PHE→intermediate → CO2 + H2O (8) h+ + OH- → ·OH (9) ROSs + PHE→intermediate → CO2 + H2O In summary, the efficient degradation of PHE in saline-alkaline soils was realised by the synergistic effect of the high adsorption and photocatalytic properties of the catalyst. First, PHE contaminants were rapidly adsorbed onto the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst surface through physical and chemical synergies. Subsequently, under visible light, the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was excited, and it produced e- CB–hVB +. A variety of ROSs were then generated through secondary reaction, such as ·O2 -, ·OH, and 1O2, which contributed to the degradation of PHE in the saline-alkaline soils. Certain adsorption effects shortened the mass transfer path of the ROS and ensured the efficient degradation of PHE within their effective half-life. During photodegradation, the possible degradation pathways of PHE were determined by the sites attacked by the active substance; the photocatalytic degradation intermediates of PHE were identified by GC–MS to infer the possible degradation pathways more rationally. Based on the intermediates listed in Table S7, the possible reaction pathways for the photocatalytic degradation of PHE were proposed ( Fig. 7). In the presence of ROSs, phenolic and ketone compounds were first formed via hydroxylation, ring opening, and oxidation. Contrary to previous reports, the 9,10-phenanthrodiol and 9–10-phenanthrodione were not detected in the GC–MS. This result was attributed the saline-alkaline soils background, which further facilitated the reaction to produce other phenolics and ketones (such as Phenol, 4-(1-methyl-1-phenylethyl)-, and 6,7-dimethoxyisoflavone) in the special soil environment[44,63]. Among them, the phenolic compounds formed 2- or 3-substituted benzene series compounds (2–4-dihydroxybenzoic acid, isophthalic acid derivatives, etc.) by hydroxylation and oxidation, followed by further oxidation to form aliphatic compounds. The ketone compounds generated phthalates and their derivatives as the main intermediates of the PHE photocatalytic degradation process by oxidation, ring opening, and esterification[64,65]. These intermediates could not only generate substituted benzene series compounds through decarboxylation to achieve further oxidation but also directly oxidise to form octadecanoic acid and heptadecanol, the main products of soil photocatalytic degradation, which was consistent with the findings in literature[64]. Ultimately, long-chain acids, long-chain lipids, and aliphatic compounds could be further mineralised to generate carbon dioxide and water, realising the efficient degradation of PHE in the saline-alkaline soils. 3.6 Remediated soil properties and environmental significance To investigate the remediation effect of the saline-alkaline soils polluted by PHE, a series of tests was performed to analyse the changes of the saline-alkaline soil properties. As shown in Table S6, the saline-alkaline soils exhibited a decrease in pH from 8.67 to 6.82. This phenomenon could be attributed to three factors. First, the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was acidic[66], and was able to regulate physicochemical properties of the saline-alkaline soils. Second, OH- in the initial soil could be oxidised by h+ to ·OH, enhancing the photocatalytic degradation while decreasing the soil pH. Third, based on the analysis of the GC–MS results, most of the substances produced in the degradation process of PHE contained carboxyl functional groups, thus making the soil less alkaline. Notably, the decreased soil pH was conducive to restoring soil health and plant growth. In addition, the anion and cation content of the soils were determined; the NO3 - content of the soils was found to decrease with increasing light duration, whereas an increasing trend was observed for the NH4 + content (Table S6). These results indicated that the electrons in the catalyst were able to reduce NO3 - to NH4 + in the saline-alkaline soil, thereby increasing the effective intake of nitrogen in the soil, promoting plant growth, and improving the soil ecological environment. 3.7 Comparative study The catalytic performance of the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst for photocatalytic degradation of PHE was compared with related porous materials of previous studies on the photocatalytic degradation of PAHs in soil, in which the PAHs degradation efficiency, reaction conditions, and soil remediation effect were comprehensively considered (Table S1). In the present study, it could be observed that the degradation efficiency of PHE over the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst was improved or comparable with other previous studies. However, compared with the studies with similar degradation efficiency, this study greatly improved the reaction conditions, which were the decisive influencing factor to determining the photocatalytic degradation efficiency. The photocatalysis time used in this study was relatively short (0.5 h), and the catalyst had a high pollution-loading capacity (200 mg·kg−1). Furthermore, using the commercially available activated carbon and Fe2O3 as reference adsorbent and photocatalyst, the degradation efficiency of PHE was also investigated. The results showed that the degradation efficiency of PHE decreased obviously under the action of activated carbon and Fe2O3, indicating that the unique structure of MIL-88A (Fe) and its iron active sites were the key to its excellent photocatalytic performance. More importantly, in contrast to most advanced oxidation processes in other studies, which were carried out under neutral or acidic conditions, the catalytic reaction in this study was conducted in a saline-alkali soil background, which made the reaction process more complicated. Notably, the simple synthesised MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst could not only degrade organic pollutants effectively, but also reduce the alkalinity of saline-alkali soil and increase the amount of easily absorbed nitrogen, thereby improving the physical and chemical properties of saline-alkali soil. From the perspective of environmental friendliness and economy, this study is more practical and feasible in the background of special saline-alkali soil. 4 Conclusions In summary, the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst with strong adsorption and photocatalytic properties was successfully prepared by a hydrothermal method, and its ability to degrade PHE and alleviate salinisation in saline-alkaline soils under simulated visible light was investigated. The results showed that the degradation of PHE could reach more than 80 % after exposure to visible light for 30 min at an initial pH of 8.67 and a water content of 40–60 %, with a pseudo-first-order kinetic constant of 0.048 min−1, which was 9.6 times higher than that for the process without a catalyst. The determination of the physicochemical properties of the soil after the photocatalytic process revealed that the pH value decreased to 6.82, effectively increasing the soil nitrogen content and improving soil fertility. Furthermore, the mechanism analysis demonstrated that the contaminants were rapidly adsorbed onto the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst surface through physical and chemical synergies. Under visible light, ·O2 -, and h+ were the main reactants for the photocatalytic degradation of PHE, followed by 1O2, and ·OH. The results suggested that the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst achieved efficient degradation of PHE in saline-alkaline soils along with the alleviation of salinisation under the synergistic action of adsorption and photocatalysis. The efficient degradation of PHE in saline-alkaline soils improved the quality of the soil environment to a certain extent and provided theoretical support for soil management. It also helped in maintaining the balance of the ecosystem and realising the sustainable use of soil. Therefore, this study provides a new approach for the remediation of PAH-contaminated saline-alkaline soils. coredata.dc:description: In arid and semi-arid areas, the remediation of saline-alkaline soils polluted by organic contaminants is challenging. In this study, the adsorption–photocatalysis synergistic removal of organic contaminants was realised using the MIL-88A(Fe) catalyst, and the saline-alkaline soils were remediated simultaneously. The adsorption isotherm of catalyst conformed to Langmuir model, and the photocatalytic degradation of PHE in an optimal visible light system achieved a PHE degradation efficiency of up to 86.2 % within 30 min. Based on the identification of active oxygen species, the PHE photocatalytic degradation was primarily driven by holes (h+) and superoxide radicals (·O2 -), followed by hydroxyl radicals (·OH) and singlet oxygen (1O2). Furthermore, the determined physical and chemical properties of the saline-alkaline soils indicated that the soil pH value decreased to 6.82, effectively increasing the absorbable nitrogen content and improving soil fertility. This study offers a new strategy for the removal of organic contaminants under special soil medium conditions.
